description.en: AREMA Ontology for building materials, buildings, natural resources, professionals, and technical constructions.

definition.en: Properties of building materials.
Properties of materials related to their acoustic behavior, such as sound absorption and sound insulation.
The sound absorption coefficient of a material at 500 Hz, defined as the ratio of the sound energy absorbed by the material to the total sound energy incident on the material.
Properties of materials that are related to their mechanical behavior, such as strength, elasticity, and durability.
The ability of a material to withstand axial loads without failure.
Density of a material, defined as its mass per unit volume.
The ability of a material to withstand tensile (pulling) forces without failure.
A measure of the stiffness of a material, defined as the ratio of stress to strain in the linear elastic region.
Properties of materials related to their moisture and thermal behavior, such as thermal conductivity and moisture permeability.
A measure of a material's ability to exchange heat with its environment, defined as the square root of the product of thermal conductivity and volumetric heat capacity.
The maximum amount of water that a material can absorb without any free water present, expressed as a percentage of the dry mass of the material.
The ability of a material to buffer changes in moisture content, defined as the ratio of the change in moisture content to the change in relative humidity.
The ratio of the volume of voids in a material to the total volume of the material, expressed as a percentage.
The ability of a material to store thermal energy, defined as the amount of heat required to change the temperature of a unit mass of the material by one degree Celsius.
The ability of a material to conduct heat, defined as the amount of heat that passes through a unit area of the material per unit time for a given temperature difference.

prefLabel.fr: Teneur en Eau à 80% d'Humidité Relative

definition.en: The water content of a material at 80% relative humidity, expressed as a percentage of the dry mass of the material.

prefLabel.fr: Résistance à la Diffusion de la Vapeur d'Eau

definition.en: The resistance of a material to the diffusion of water vapor, defined as the ratio of the water vapor pressure difference across the material to the water vapor flux through the material.
The ability of a material to withstand fire or heat without significant degradation or failure.

prefLabel.en: Reaction to Fire Class DIN EN 13501-1
prefLabel.de: Reaktion auf Feuer Klasse DIN EN 13501-1
prefLabel.fr: Classe de Réaction au Feu DIN EN 13501-1

definition.en: The classification of a material's reaction to fire according to the DIN EN 13501-1 standard, which assesses the fire performance of construction products.
A general term for any physical entity that can be identified and described.
Exemplary buildings or structures made with a earnest commitment to using regenerative materials.
Buildings sporting multiple storeys.
Buildings primarily used for commercial office purposes.
Buildings intended for use by the public, such as schools, libraries, or government offices.
Basic or minimal buildings or structures, typically with limited complexity or use.
Buildings intended for a smaller amount of inhabitants
Persons or organizations providing services or materials around regenerative materials.
A professional responsible for designing buildings
An organization promoting either a way of building or the professionals using it
A specialist focusing on the physical properties of buildings, including thermal, acoustic, and energy performance.
A professional specializing in the design, construction, and maintenance of infrastructure and buildings.
A company engaged in building construction projects and services.
A skilled worker specializing in manual trades related to construction
A company or individual involved in the production and supply of construction materials.
A academic or industrial researcher with expertise in regenerative materials
Company or individual reselling building materials
Materials made out of resources by transformation and processing for the purpose of building.
Blocks of various formats depending on density, preferences, available forms and purposes.
Loose building materials used to fill voids
Building Materials that can be processed to become massive, homogene building elements. They can be load-bearing or not and are mostly in need of formwork.
Mixes of a binder, fillers and sometimes additives to bond Brick or to plaster or render surfaces.
Prefabricated flat building materials, designed for different purposes as panelling and/or insulation
Resources that can potentially be used for construction; both occuring naturally (like bio- or geo-sourced) or being salvaged from demoltions.
Naturally occuring resource in the sub-soil containing clay as binder for silts and sands in different proportions.
Hemp
Fibrous plants other than cereals or hemp
Natural rocks that can be found the bedrock
Dried stalks of cereals
Wood
Constructions using building materials to become building elements.
Load-bearing elements of a building
Structure outside exterior wall
Separation between storeys
Load-bearing elements usually indoors
Wall that separates the exterior from teh interior of the building above ground
Wall that separates the exterior from teh interior of the building under ground
Slab that represents the floor at ground level
Foundation of a structure, either underground or above, to transmit the forces applied by the structure to the ground, underground or bedrock
Structural wall inside the building
Roof construction load-bearing
Stair
Finishing elements of a building, such as wall coverings, floor coverings, and ceiling finishes.
Ceiling Finishing
Floor Covering
Interior Door
Interior Wall Finishing
Partition Wall, non load-bearing
The outer shell of a building, including walls, roofs, and windows, that separates the interior from the exterior environment.
Openings in walls such as doors and windows
A door is a structure to enter or exit a room
A window is a structure to let light or air into a room
External Thermal Insulation
Facade finishing above ground
External wall finishing under ground
Roof Covering
Sun & Weather Protection
Other concepts not fitting into the main categories of the AREMA Ontology.
Technical Equipement as Heating, Ventilation, Water or electricity supply
